Issues.Title: fix(ivy): restore NG defs after running tests in TestBed
Issues.Body:
`R3TestBed` allows consumers to configure a "testing module", declare components, override various metadata, etc. To do this, it implements its own JIT compilation, where components/directives/modules have Ivy definition fields generated based on testing metadata. It results in tests interfering with each other. One test might override something in a component that another test tries to use normally, causing failures.

In order to resolve this problem, we store current components/directives/modules defs before applying overrides and re-compiling. Once the test is complete, we restore initial defs, so the next tests interact with "clean" components.

**NOTE: this PR is based on another one (PR #27693), so please have a look at this commit only:** https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/6a30d7103ea1840ba7a0e109f1618e6d1ec01d50 .

This PR resolves FW-872.

Issues.Title: feat(ivy): implement `compileComponents` method for `TestBedRender3`
Issues.Body:
The implementation of the `compileComponents` method for `TestBedRender3` was missing.
We now pass each component through `resolveComponentResources` when `TestBed.compileComponents` is called so that `templateUrl` and `styleUrls` can be resolved asynchronously and used once `TestBed.createComponent` is called.
The component's metadata are overriden in `TestBed` instead of mutating the original metadata like this is the case outside of TestBed. The reason for that is that we need to ensure that we didn't mutate anything so that the following tests can run with the same original metadata, otherwise we it could trigger or hide some errors.

Issues.Title: ci: compute commit range for rerun workflows
Issues.Body:
On push builds, CircleCI provides `CIRCLE_COMPARE_URL`, which we use to extract the commit range for a given build. When a workflow is rerun (e.g. to recover from a flaked job), `CIRCLE_COMPARE_URL` is not defined, causing some jobs to fail.

This commit fixes it by retrieving the compare URL from the original workflow. It uses a slow process involving a (potentially large) number of requests to CircleCI API.
It depends on the (undocumented) fact, that the `workspace_id` is the same on all rerun workflows and the same as the original `workflow_id`.

Issues.Title: ES2015 iteration not supported
Issues.Body:
Iterating over an ES2015 collection is not supported in our compilation. Ex:

```javascript
const edges = new Set([1, 2, 3]);
for (const edge of edges) { ... }
```

It gets transpiled correctly when built under Bazel, but will fail on Travis in the old `build.sh` system, as that uses a set of `tsconfig`s and a version of TS that don't seem to support it. The error is:

```
error TS2569: Type 'Set<T>' is not an array type or a string type. Use compiler option '--downlevelIteration' to allow iterating of iterators.
```

Issues.Title: Clarity and/or discussion on "private" property/method naming
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ“š Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description I was hoping to gain more clarity or talk about a "nice to have" in regards to the [Angular Styleguide suggestion](https://angular.io/guide/styleguide#properties-and-methods) not to use the underscore prefix for "private" properties and methods if possible. Specifically, it's use and the way "private" interacts from ts within templates between the default dev and prod builds - it seems like there could be a gap here. [This question ](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/27615) helps illustrate part of the issue, and has been talked about at length in a few more references (and more), [here_1](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/26393), [here_2](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/16893). While these talk more specifically about access methods conflicting with prop names, I wanted to bring up the interaction with templates. Issues [like this one](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/27615), while they are not a problem with the framework, throwing an error that a property is "private" while looking at the template currently requires extra step(s) ([explained more here](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/11978#issuecomment-255736505)). While JavaScript (default ng serve / ES5) does not care about "private," tsc (default prod build) does.TS has support for letting the developer know if a private property or method is being used, but I'm not familiar with a way of seeing this in the templates. Developers who are more familiar with Angular may not have an issue here, but using a pattern like this could be a "nice to have" for newer/unfamiliar developers, or a timesaving naming/visual pattern when working in templates. ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/guide/styleguide#properties-and-methods ### Reproduction Steps** ``` ng new test-ng cd test-ng ``` Inside of app.component.ts: ``` public test = 'test'; private testPrivate = 'testPrivate'; private _testPrivate = '_testPrivate'; ``` and inside of app.component.html: ```
{{test}}
{{testPrivate}}
{{_testPrivate}}
``` Running the default `ng serve` works just fine as expected / noted above, but `ng build --prod` will fail (also as expected). The difference (at least for me) is that with the IDEs I've used, I can immediately tell by looking just at the template that `_testPrivate` probably is private- ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** Actual behavior: while it's an agreed upon mistake by the developer, no ahead of time warning for private props/methods in templates, requires additional steps. Expected: Can be a range from noting the alternative naming with underscore, adding more detail to the existing info of TS vs JS "private", or leave the docs alone and provide/suggest tooling out of the box that catches this at dev time.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Clarity and/or discussion on "private" property/method naming" (#27760)

Issues.Title: Add tests for elide imports and fix named imports with default imports
Issues.Body:
- test: add tests for elide imports
This also adds the option to provide addition files when using `createTypescriptContext` this is paramount for the elide imports tests as without this certain symbols won't have the full details.

Which will cause tests to be false positive and re-surface issues like #13212


- fix(@ngtools/webpack): drop only unused default import when used withâ€¦  â€¦
â€¦ named imports

At the moment when having a default import together with a named import example:
```
import abc, { def } from './foo';
```

And the default import becomes unused it will drop the entire node which will caused used named imports to be dropped as well.

- refactor: use `getExportSpecifierLocalTargetSymbol` and `getShorthandAssignmentValueSymbol` to handle symbols lookups

Use typechecker methods to handle special cases for `ExportSpecifier` and `ShorthandPropertyAssignment`

Issues.Title: Proposal: auto increment build budgets
Issues.Body:
<!--
IF YOU DON'T FILL OUT THE FOLLOWING INFORMATION YOUR ISSUE MIGHT BE CLOSED WITHOUT INVESTIGATING
-->
### Bug Report or Feature Request (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] bug report -> please search issues before submitting
- [x] feature request
```

### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Versions
<!--
Output from: `node --version`, `npm --version` and `ng --version`.
  Windows (7/8/10). Linux (incl. distribution). macOS (El Capitan? Sierra? High Sierra?)
-->
node - 8.12.0
npm - 6.4.1
ng - 7.0.4
macOS - Sierra

### Repro steps
<!--
Simple steps to reproduce this bug.
Please include: commands run (incl args), packages added, related code changes.
A link to a sample repo would help too.
-->
n/a

### The log given by the failure
<!-- Normally this include a stack trace and some more information. -->
n/a

### Story

At my job, we have built our own library of shared angular components. We have budget sizes configured in the `angular.json`. As with any active project, the bundle size tends to increase over time. That can cause our automated pull request tests to fail on even a small code change if the change adds enough size to go over the max/min threshold (5% in this example).

"budgets": [{
								"type": "bundle",
								"name": "main",
								"baseline": "4020kb",
								"minimumError": "5%",
								"maximumError": "5%"
							},{
								"type": "bundle",
								"name": "styles",
								"baseline": "181kb",
								"minimumError": "5%",
								"maximumError": "5%"
							}]


When this happens, the error is easy to identify and remedy (thanks for that!). However, this puts us in a tricky situation. 
> ng build --prod
  
> Date: 2018-12-19T20:13:36.383Z
> Hash: 9ee44adbae1ca37d967f
> Time: 59917ms
> chunk {0} runtime.ec2944dd8b20ec099bf3.js (runtime) 1.41 kB [entry] [rendered]
> chunk {1} main.2e3d8a71c52f17d81367.js (main) 1.39 MB [initial] [rendered]
> chunk {2} polyfills.f31412eb35fb595ae0a2.js (polyfills) 147 kB [initial] [rendered]
> chunk {3} styles.c38cc6ec26a52983595d.css (styles) 170 kB [initial] [rendered]
> 
> ERROR in budgets, maximum exceeded for main. Budget 1.4 MB was exceeded by 1.39 kB.

- If we pick a min/max threshold that is **larger**, it increases the chance of introducing a bad import or dependency that dramatically increases the bundle size. 
- If we pick a min/max threshold that is **smaller**, it increases the occurrence of small code changes that push us past our budget.

Budget sizes are known to be a difficult configuration to determine. @jenniferfell has an open item for this topic https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/26106

### Desired functionality
<!--
What would like to see implemented?
What is the usecase?
-->

An optional configuration to auto increment your budget sizes would allow developers to set a comfortable max/min amount that their bundle is allowed to change in size. This could be baked into the `build` command or a new command that would ideally be used before `build`. This would allow your budgets to update organically with your project size but large changes (like adding or removing a third party dependency) would require a manual adjustment to the budget baseline.

#### Example use:

An organization has an `angular.json` file with a configuration that allows for auto updating when the difference in bundle size is less than 5%.

"budgets": [{
								"type": "bundle",
								"name": "main",
								"baseline": "4020kb",
								"minimumAutoIncrement": "5%",
								"maximumAutoIncrement": "5%",
                                                                   "autoIncrement": "true"
							},{
								"type": "bundle",
								"name": "styles",
								"baseline": "181kb",
								"minimumError": "5%",
								"maximumError": "5%",
                                                                   "autoIncrement": "false" // this would default to false to not break existing usage
							}]

User A works and commits their final change. Before pushing a branch up, they run the optional build command (or a new command) `ng build --update-budget` and then commit the updated `angular.json`. When User B reviews the PR, they would notice that the budget baseline value was adjusted to equal the old budget +/- the delta amount of the code change. Budget sizes that exceed the min/max auto increment configuration would still throw an error and maintain their role as a warning to large bundle size changes.

### Mention any other details that might be useful
<!-- Please include a link to the repo if this is related to an OSS project. -->

Incorporating this into version control/continuous integrated environments could be tricky as the Angular-CLI would be modifying versioned files and not the user. 

An individual solution that uses the [Bundle-Budget plugin](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/plugins/bundle-budget.ts) to increment the bundle size could be built and added to a company's existing processes.

Figured it was an interesting enough issue to discuss here. Thank you.

Issues.Title: TemplatePortal class signature: possible typo
Issues.Body:
It seems like the `TemplatePortal` class signature

https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/fe7f95ec10acd9e660f7037be8d006c9e264a57b/src/cdk/portal/portal.ts#L119 

should actually be 

```ts
    export class TemplatePortal<C = any> extends Portal<EmbeddedViewRef<C>> {
```

and

https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/fe7f95ec10acd9e660f7037be8d006c9e264a57b/src/cdk/portal/portal.ts#L145

should be

```ts
    attach(host: PortalOutlet, context: C | undefined = this.context): EmbeddedViewRef<C> {
```

The generic parameter for `Portal` is for the type that the `attach(host: PortalOutlet): T` method returns. That returns what `PortalOutlet` 's `attach(portal: Portal<any>): any;` returns. _Note: This could be `attach<T>(portal: Portal<T>): T;` couldn't it_ If you look at the implementation of `PortalOutlet`, `BasePortalOutlet`, it's overload for `attach()` when passing a `TemplatePortal` is `attach<T>(portal: TemplatePortal<T>): EmbeddedViewRef<T>;` not `attach<T>(portal: TemplatePortal<T>): T;` like you'd expect based on the `TemplatePortal` class signature.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "TemplatePortal class signature: possible typo" (#14584)

Issues.Title: Branch manager should check diff instead of patch
Issues.Body:
Consider you have multiple commits within a PR, first commits adds a file, second commit renames the file.

The patch for that change will not apply with `git apply` because the patches are not run sequentially and therefore `git apply` will throw when it tries renaming the file in the second commit.

e.g. 

```patch
From 5fa1e23cb00a04c9b084f8634c7e7cea9b413d8e Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Paul Gschwendtner <paulgschwendtner@gmail.com>
Date: Wed, 19 Dec 2018 20:54:09 +0100
Subject: [PATCH] My second PR commit

---
 srcs/my-file.txt => my-new-name-file.txt | 0
 1 file changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
 rename srcs/my-file.txt => my-new-name-file.txt (100%)

diff --git a/srcs/my-file.txt b/my-new-name-file.txt
similarity index 100%
rename from srcs/my-file.txt
rename to my-new-name-file.txt
-- 
2.19.1.windows.1

From aaa9e380164af93d92982aca740bb56696ae2879 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Paul Gschwendtner <paulgschwendtner@gmail.com>
Date: Wed, 19 Dec 2018 20:53:54 +0100
Subject: [PATCH] First PR commit

---
 srcs/my-file.txt | 0
 1 file changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
 create mode 100644 srcs/my-file.txt

diff --git a/srcs/my-file.txt b/srcs/my-file.txt
new file mode 100644
index 0000000..e69de29
-- 
2.19.1.windows.1
```

We should rather just check the PR's `.diff` file that just reflects the difference and nothing more. This also makes sure that subsequent commits in a PR can become green if previous commits didn't apply properly. As an example: see #14565
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Branch manager should check diff instead of patch" (#14582)

Issues.Title: CDK Overlay: ViewportMargin per side
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.

It would be nice to be able to define the viewport margin for each side independently (similar to a css margin).

Something like

```ts
interface ViewportMargin {
    top: number,
    right: number,
    bottom: number,
    left: number
}

viewPortMargin: number | ViewportMargin;
```

would be nice to have.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?

I'd like to make sure my overlay is only shown within the "main" area of my application and not on top of the action bar or sidenav. (Injecting a custom OverlayContainer and a second Overlay service instance limited to my desired area doesn't work since it still uses the ViewportRuler for calculation).

#### Is there anything else we should know?
